mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (17 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div></div>


<p><strong>It has been eight years</strong> since the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance exchanges launched in 2014.</p>

<p>During that time, the individual market has been highly fluid, with insurer participation, pricing, and plan types evolving dynamically from year to year. The 2022 open-enrollment period (OEP) allows for an assessment of the latest movements in the individual health insurance market.</p>

<p>Several salient features have emerged, particularly in light of the substantive changes created by the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021. Using data scraped from nearly every health insurance exchange in the country, McKinsey’s Center for US Health System Reform has uncovered critical insights relevant to consumers, payers, providers, private equity sponsors, and policy analysts.</p>

<p>The Center for US Health System Reform’s analysis of the 2022 OEP led to the following conclusions:</p>

<ul>
<li>Insurer participation and new product offerings have accelerated in the past four years (the halfway point since the marketplace launched), with levels near or surpassing their all-time peaks.</li>
<li>Managed-care plans—particularly health maintenance organization (HMO) plans and exclusive provider organization (EPO) plans—have grown steadily since 2014 and now account for 82 percent of plan type offerings.</li>
<li>Consumers increasingly have access to more insurer choices and plans in their home counties; only about 2 percent of consumers have access to just one insurer.</li>
<li>Across all plan tiers, prices (premiums) remained largely stable, with only slightly higher price increases in 2022 than in 2021; consumer cost burden was also reduced by additional subsidies created by the American Rescue Plan Act.</li>
<li>Annual premium growth of plans in the 15 states with section 1332 innovation waivers was observably lower than similar plans in the 35 states plus Washington, DC, without waivers.</li>
</ul>

<p>Overall, the individual market has continued its recent trajectory of increased participation by insurers and consumers. Pricing has largely stabilized in the past several years, and consumer access has grown as newer, tech-enabled insurers bring greater choice to the market.</p>

<p>But uncertainty remains, in part because the enhanced premium subsidies created by the American Rescue Plan Act are due to expire at the end of 2022. If Congress does not renew these subsidies, pricing and consumer participation may face headwinds in the 2023 OEP.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-edge-to-edge StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__TLkZC mck-c-module-wrapper"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>2022 brought healthy participation growth</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>In 2022, 55 new insurers entered the market (a 21 percent increase over 2021), marking the highest growth in participation since 2015, when participation grew 26 percent.</p>
<p>Participation in the past two years has exceeded the 252 insurers that initially entered in 2014, with 305 total insurers in 2022.</p>
<p>Insurer participation has nearly reached its 2015 high of 310 insurers.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>The individual market has continued its trajectory of increased participation by insurers, with 55 insurers entering the market in 2022.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh01-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Insurer participation increased in 2022 for the fourth straight year." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh01-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>In-market growth represented about 50 percent of total product growth between 2021 and 2022, accounting for a larger share of total growth than during any of the previous four years, highlighting insurers’ strategy of competing on the number and variety of offerings in the market.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>50% of 2021–22 growth driven by in-market growth</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh02-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Product offerings grew significantly from 2021 to 2022, with incumbents driving higher growth than new entrants." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh02-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Tech-enabled and Medicaid plans, such as Oscar and Bright Health, have seen substantial growth since 2014, contributing the most to overall participation growth, while other types have declined or stayed relatively stagnant.</p>
<p>Conversely, participation among Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan (CO-OP) insurers has largely declined since 2016.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Tech-enabled and Medicaid plans have contributed the most to overall participation growth since 2014.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh03-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Insurer participation in health insurance exchanges increased across insurer types from 2021 to 2022." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh03-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Preferred provider organization (PPO) plans have sharply declined by 36 percentage points in the same time frame.</p>
<p>Health maintenance organization (HMO) plans have grown steadily since 2014 as a share of plan types, displacing PPO offerings.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>82% of all plan type offerings are managed-care plans.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh04-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Managed-care plans have steadily grown since 2014 and now account for 82 percent of plan type offerings." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh04-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Bronze plans have seen the most growth of any tier type since the creation of the market.</p>
<p>Catastrophic and platinum plans, conversely, have gradually become less available since 2014.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>37% of 2022 plan type offerings are bronze, which have seen the most growth of any tier type.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh05-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Silver and bronze plans have expanded since 2014 and now account for 75 percent of plan type offerings." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh05-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Medicaid and tech-enabled insurers have been <strong>narrowing the accessibility gap since around 2018</strong>, with about 75 percent and 50 percent of consumers, respectively, having access to such a plan in 2022.</p>
<p><strong>CO-OP plans have precipitously become less available</strong> to consumers since 2017 as these insurers have reduced their participation in the market overall.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Consumer access has grown as newer, tech-enabled insurers bring greater choice to the market.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh06-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Consumer access to insurer types increased or stayed the same between 2021 and 2022, continuing an upward trend since 2018." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh06-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Counties with high insurer participation (defined as more than five insurers) remain in the minority.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>94% of counties have more than one insurer participating in the market.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh07-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The proportion of counties with a single insurer decreased from 52 percent in 2018 to 6 percent in 2022." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh07-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div></div></div></div><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__item__YhXnX"><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-item__fg74z"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-md StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-text__DEQ4O StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-4"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div>Well more than half of consumers can choose from five or more plans</div></h2><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline"><div><p>Counties with one participating insurer account for just 2 percent of the overall consumer population in 2022, down from one-quarter of consumers in 2018.</p>
<p>The proportion of consumers with access to five or more insurers jumped 17 percentage points from 44 percent in 2021 to 61 percent in 2022, indicating that the relatively few counties with such high participation levels still represent a majority of the market population.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>61% of consumers in 2022 have access to five or more insurers.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh08-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="About 2 percent of consumers have access to just one insurer, while 87 percent of consumers have at least three insurer options." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh08-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Gold plans in particular saw average price reductions in 2022—the largest reductions of any plan tier since the marketplace launched in 2014.</p>
<p>Also in 2022, platinum plans became less expensive for the first time, capping off years of decelerating price increases.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Premiums remained largely stable or saw reductions in 2022, and consumer cost burden was reduced by additional subsidies created by the American Rescue Plan Act.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh09-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Across all metal tiers, prices remained stable or became slightly less expensive between 2021 and 2022. <p>Enrollees in national plans were more than two times as likely to be exposed to premium increases of more than 7.5 percent (in the lowest-priced silver plan).</p>
<blockquote>
<p>15% of enrollees in national plans were exposed to a significant increase (7.5 percent or more) in premiums.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh10-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Overall, most silver plans became less expensive in 2022, with few consumers seeing a price increase of more than 7.5 percent." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh10-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <p>Tech-enabled plans offered substantial price decreases while also maintaining a meaningful presence in the market.</p>
<p>Blue and regional plans were the only plans with median price increases across the lowest-price silver plans.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>3% price increase in Blues plans.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh11-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Tech-enabled and Consumer Operated and Oriented Plans (CO-OPs) saw the largest price drops in 2022, while Blues increased prices by 3 percent on average." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh11-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. That share rose to 20 percent in 2020 and 18 percent in 2022.</p>
<p>Blues and Medicaid account for 36 percent of participating insurers in 2022 and are most likely to offer the lowest-priced plan option.</p>
<p>The percentage of consumers whose most affordable silver plan option was offered by a national or CO-OP insurer dropped from 40 percent in 2015 to 6 percent in 2021 and 4 percent in 2022.</p>
<p>These shifts are driven partly by participation; 33 percent of insurers at the state level in 2015 were national or CO-OP, compared with only 15 percent in 2022.</p></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh12-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Blue and Medicaid plans are the lowest-premium option for about half of consumers, while national and Consumer Operated and Oriented Plans (CO-OPs) tend to be less competitive." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh12-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <blockquote>
<p>Annual premium growth of silver plans in the 15 states with reinsurance programs was observably lower than similar plans in the 35 states (plus Washington, DC) without programs, in most cases.</p>
</blockquote></div></div></div><div class="StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__content-media__o8N4Z StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky__EK8hB StoryContainer_mck-c-story-container__container-sticky--extra-spacing__uDmVE mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-8"><div class=""><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh13-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Fifteen states have reinsurance programs, including one new program in 2022." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/insights%20into%20the%202022%20individual%20health%20insurance%20market/svg-ind-market-insights-2022-exh13-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h2>Methodology</h2>

<p>The findings in this document are based on publicly available information. The 2014–22 rates come from McKinsey’s Healthcare Insights exchange tracking tool, which includes county- and plan-level information from publicly available rate filings and from HealthCare.gov. The consumer population is defined as the population that has enrolled in any type of individual coverage, including both on- and off-exchange plans. Enrollment for 2022 is projected.</p>

<p>Because of data availability limitations, the analysis excludes some counties:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>2020:</em> Herkimer, Montgomery, Orleans, Saratoga, Schuyler, Tompkins, Washington, Wayne, and Wyoming counties in New York (combined estimated enrollment is 12,969)</li>
<li><em>2021:</em> Chemung, Erie, Montgomery, Orleans, Saratoga, Washington, Wayne, and Wyoming counties in New York (combined estimated enrollment is 20,427)</li>
<li><em>2022:</em> All New Mexico counties because their state-based exchange limits data scraping (combined estimated enrollment is 43,018); population not available for Kalawao County, Hawaii, in 2021 and 2022 (three estimated individual market enrollees in 2020)</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Pricing:</strong> All analyses in this document are for exchange plans only; this report does not include off-exchange pricing data. For consistency, prices were obtained for a 27-year-old nonsmoking individual without family or partner coverage. To understand the premium changes that individuals face, we calculated the weighted average rate change in premiums in each relevant year for the lowest-priced silver plan in each rating area or county combination and combined those data with the distribution of individuals using individual market plans in each county, as designated by Federal Information Process Standards (FIPS) county codes.</p>

<p><strong>Insurer participation:</strong> To calculate insurer participation counts, we analyzed the number of unique insurer parents that are offering plans on exchange, either by state or by county, depending on the analysis. To analyze access, we combined those data with the distribution of individuals using individual market plans in each county (designated by FIPS codes).</p>

<p><strong>Plan types:</strong> Plan types reported here were taken directly from insurer rate filings and summary of benefits and coverage documents. Independent assessment of plan types was not part of the analysis presented in this document. Plan types are defined as follows:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>HMO:</em> A health maintenance organization typically centers around a primary-care physician who acts as gatekeeper to other services and referrals; it usually provides no coverage for out-of-network services, except in emergency or urgent-care situations.</li>
<li><em>EPO:</em> An exclusive provider organization is similar to an HMO. It usually provides no coverage for any services delivered by out-of-network providers or facilities except in emergency or urgent-care situations; however, it generally does not require members to use a primary-care physician for in-network referrals.</li>
<li><em>PPO:</em> A preferred provider organization typically allows members to see physicians and get services that are not part of a network, but out-of-network services often require a higher copayment.</li>
<li><em>POS:</em> A point-of-service plan is a hybrid of an HMO and a PPO; it is an open-access model that may assign members to a primary-care physician and usually provides partial coverage for out-of-network services.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Insurer types are defined as follows:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li><em>Blue:</em> A Blue Cross Blue Shield payer</li>
<li><em>Consumer Operated and Oriented Plan (CO-OP):</em> A recipient of federal CO-OP grant funding that was not a commercial payer before 2014</li>
<li><em>Medicaid:</em> An insurer that offered only Medicaid insurance prior to 2014</li>
<li><em>National:</em> A commercial payer with a presence on exchanges</li>
<li><em>Provider:</em> An insurer that also operates as a provider or health system</li>
<li><em>Regional or local:</em> A commercial payer with a presence typically in a single state, but may be in multiple states</li>
<li><em>Tech-enabled:</em> Any payer from the parent companies Bright Health, Friday Health Plans, or Oscar</li>
</ul></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid analysis of the individual health insurance market and outlines trends in products, plans, and prices from 2014 to 2022."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"McKinsey’s Center for US Health System Reform 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt has been eight years\u003c/strong\u003e since the Affordable Care Act\u0026rsquo;s health insurance exchanges launched in 2014.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDuring that time, the individual market has been highly fluid, with insurer participation, pricing, and plan types evolving dynamically from year to year. The 2022 open-enrollment period (OEP) allows for an assessment of the latest movements in the individual health insurance market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral salient features have emerged, particularly in light of the substantive changes created by the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021. Using data scraped from nearly every health insurance exchange in the country, McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Center for US Health System Reform has uncovered critical insights relevant to consumers, payers, providers, private equity sponsors, and policy analysts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe Center for US Health System Reform\u0026rsquo;s analysis of the 2022 OEP led to the following conclusions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eInsurer participation and new product offerings have accelerated in the past four years (the halfway point since the marketplace launched), with levels near or surpassing their all-time peaks.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eManaged-care plans\u0026mdash;particularly health maintenance organization (HMO) plans and exclusive provider organization (EPO) plans\u0026mdash;have grown steadily since 2014 and now account for 82 percent of plan type offerings.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConsumers increasingly have access to more insurer choices and plans in their home counties; only about 2 percent of consumers have access to just one insurer.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAcross all plan tiers, prices (premiums) remained largely stable, with only slightly higher price increases in 2022 than in 2021; consumer cost burden was also reduced by additional subsidies created by the American Rescue Plan Act.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAnnual premium growth of plans in the 15 states with section 1332 innovation waivers was observably lower than similar plans in the 35 states plus Washington, DC, without waivers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, the individual market has continued its recent trajectory of increased participation by insurers and consumers. Pricing has largely stabilized in the past several years, and consumer access has grown as newer, tech-enabled insurers bring greater choice to the market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBut uncertainty remains, in part because the enhanced premium subsidies created by the American Rescue Plan Act are due to expire at the end of 2022. If Congress does not renew these subsidies, pricing and consumer participation may face headwinds in the 2023 OEP.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[story 1]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003eMethodology\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe findings in this document are based on publicly available information. The 2014\u0026ndash;22 rates come from McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Healthcare Insights exchange tracking tool, which includes county- and plan-level information from publicly available rate filings and from HealthCare.gov. The consumer population is defined as the population that has enrolled in any type of individual coverage, including both on- and off-exchange plans. Enrollment for 2022 is projected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBecause of data availability limitations, the analysis excludes some counties:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e2020:\u003c/em\u003e Herkimer, Montgomery, Orleans, Saratoga, Schuyler, Tompkins, Washington, Wayne, and Wyoming counties in New York (combined estimated enrollment is 12,969)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e2021:\u003c/em\u003e Chemung, Erie, Montgomery, Orleans, Saratoga, Washington, Wayne, and Wyoming counties in New York (combined estimated enrollment is 20,427)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e2022:\u003c/em\u003e All New Mexico counties because their state-based exchange limits data scraping (combined estimated enrollment is 43,018); population not available for Kalawao County, Hawaii, in 2021 and 2022 (three estimated individual market enrollees in 2020)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePricing:\u003c/strong\u003e All analyses in this document are for exchange plans only; this report does not include off-exchange pricing data. For consistency, prices were obtained for a 27-year-old nonsmoking individual without family or partner coverage. To understand the premium changes that individuals face, we calculated the weighted average rate change in premiums in each relevant year for the lowest-priced silver plan in each rating area or county combination and combined those data with the distribution of individuals using individual market plans in each county, as designated by Federal Information Process Standards (FIPS) county codes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInsurer participation:\u003c/strong\u003e To calculate insurer participation counts, we analyzed the number of unique insurer parents that are offering plans on exchange, either by state or by county, depending on the analysis. To analyze access, we combined those data with the distribution of individuals using individual market plans in each county (designated by FIPS codes).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePlan types:\u003c/strong\u003e Plan types reported here were taken directly from insurer rate filings and summary of benefits and coverage documents. Independent assessment of plan types was not part of the analysis presented in this document. Plan types are defined as follows:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHMO:\u003c/em\u003e A health maintenance organization typically centers around a primary-care physician who acts as gatekeeper to other services and referrals; it usually provides no coverage for out-of-network services, except in emergency or urgent-care situations.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEPO:\u003c/em\u003e An exclusive provider organization is similar to an HMO. It usually provides no coverage for any services delivered by out-of-network providers or facilities except in emergency or urgent-care situations; however, it generally does not require members to use a primary-care physician for in-network referrals.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePPO:\u003c/em\u003e A preferred provider organization typically allows members to see physicians and get services that are not part of a network, but out-of-network services often require a higher copayment.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePOS:\u003c/em\u003e A point-of-service plan is a hybrid of an HMO and a PPO; it is an open-access model that may assign members to a primary-care physician and usually provides partial coverage for out-of-network services.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eInsurer types are defined as follows:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBlue:\u003c/em\u003e A Blue Cross Blue Shield payer\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsumer Operated and Oriented Plan (CO-OP):\u003c/em\u003e A recipient of federal CO-OP grant funding that was not a commercial payer before 2014\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMedicaid:\u003c/em\u003e An insurer that offered only Medicaid insurance prior to 2014\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eNational:\u003c/em\u003e A commercial payer with a presence on exchanges\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProvider:\u003c/em\u003e An insurer that also operates as a provider or health system\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRegional or local:\u003c/em\u003e A commercial payer with a presence typically in a single state, but may be in multiple states\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTech-enabled:\u003c/em\u003e Any payer from the parent companies Bright Health, Friday Health Plans, or 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCO-OP plans have precipitously become less available\u003c/strong\u003e to consumers since 2017 as these insurers have reduced their participation 2014.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso in 2022, platinum plans became less expensive for the first time, capping off years of decelerating price increases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePremiums remained largely stable or saw reductions in 2022, and consumer cost burden was reduced by additional subsidies created by the
